1601196324_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnX.body:
i recommend against dual booting windows and linux. if you really need to run windows, you should either do it in a vm, or with a separate machine.

microsoft hijacks your bootloader all the time when windows updates, which gets incredibly annoying. moreso, when dual booting, microsoft has the power to scan your linux partition while youre booted into windows, and if you use full disk encryption, they have enough power to inject a keylogger into your bootloader when you type your decryption password. that doesnt mean they do, or would, but in my opinion, if you dont think microsoft will go that far, youre not paranoid enough.

then again, if you had full disk encryption on your linux partition, and microsoft were to tamper with your bootloader, the hashes would show up different, and if you want to go through the trouble of checking hashes and warning us if it turns out to be true, be my guest. but in my opinion its not worth the trouble.

theres also plenty more attacks they can do with full hardware access, take for example, injecting code into your roms. im not worried about that though, because we already know new intel and amd chips do have hardware backdoors (intel me/amd psp).

me personally, i dont run windows on any of my machines anymore. almost all my games and software are either open source, have native linux builds, or run on proton just fine. i run all closed source software in a sandbox, except for my nvidia drivers, which im trying to move away from.

switching drives might be safe and paranoid enough. but you should physically disconnect the drives like you said you wouldnt have to do.

> [ssdifnskdjfnsdjk](#comment_146_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS): in this case my aim is more about anonymity than the privacy, but i am wondering why you are saying this, do you mean the risk of exit node capturing the plain (unencrypted) HTTP traffic? If i make sure i toriffy only the major sites that are using https, i think the risks of leaking plain password would be minimal.

if its anonymity you care about, proxying through tor is not good enough. webrtc routes outside of your socks proxy, so it will end up going through clearnet, and websites can use that to unanonymize you. tor browser takes care of this by blocking webrtc. you should be able to do the same for your browser, and if not, you could probably patch your browser if its open source.

if you can patch it you should be fine, unless theres another protocol that routes outside of your proxy the same way.
